subject: RE: [junit] Separate Assertion Object
msgSnippet: So said  Manuel Amago  on  2003-02-03 -------------------- ... could ... object ... cooked ... Assert ... Why have custom methods? Why not simply implement
messageBody:
So said Manuel Amago on 2003-02-03 --------------------

>> > We don't even have to lose the namespace convenience: TestCase
could
>
>> > implement the assertion interface and delegate to a separate
object
>> > specified at, say, construction time.
>
>This is a neat idea, the only problem is that you cannot publish the
>whole of the Assert interface up-front. This will mean that you would
>have to use workarounds like using the boolean assert methods, or
>writing a whole Assert framework based on reflection.
>
>For clarity's sake, let us imagine that your company uses its own
cooked
>version of the Date class: MyDate. (Don't ask me why they'd do this,
>its just an example. :^) It is the company standard that you use this
>class anywhere where you would otherwise use the java API Date class.
>Thus, we can see the utility of having a reusable custom Assert class
>with different MyDate assert signatures, for use across different
>company projects.
>
>However, this custom class could never have been part of jUnit's
Assert
>API, so how would you include these custom methods?
>
>(Examples of methods to include would be:
> void assertEquals(MyDate expected, MyDate actual);
> void assertEquals(String msg, MyDate expected, MyDate actual);
> void assertEquals(MyDate expected, MyDate actual, MyDate delta);
> void assertEquals(String msg, MyDate expected, MyDate actual, MyDate
>delta);
>)

Why have custom methods? Why not simply implement equals()
appropriately? Is this old ground? :)
